job_title: Emergency Care Technician in Tallahassee, FL
pros: The staff at TMH NE ED is very friendly & it's a great place to work
cons: I guess pay could be better, but it's pretty standard for the industry

review_title: Generally good people, but low-ball pay
pros: Your coworkers will generally be good people. I made a lot of friends my time there. I also learned a lot, being a nurse extern, I was able to get many hands-on opportunities when i put myself out there. Very flexible shifts, I worked as much or as little as I could depending on my classes or other job at the time.
cons: There are always some bad apples who have superiority complexes and don't know how to communicate respectfully or professionally. Also, there will be many times when you are the only extern on the floor. This leaves you with the responsibility for helping all the nurses and the patients which is overwhelming and virtually impossible. The pay has improved in recent months but still low in comparison to nearby areas.

review_title: Workplace Bullying, Low pay, everyone is miserable
pros: We got to make our own schedules to an extent on our floor. Okay to start out with as a new grad. Some seasoned nurses are supportive.
cons: The pay is the worst. The offer no incentive to come in extra. Holiday pay is NOT time and a half. No parental/maternity leave. No one cares if a nurse is overwhelmed they just tell you to call the hotline. PTO is denied consistently due to nurse shortage. Seasoned nurses are bitter that new grad nurses are getting paid more than them and retaliate against the new nurses.

review_title: A Great Reputation but empty promises
job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Tallahassee, FL
pros: Fast pace environment, exposure to a variety of patients.
cons: Low pay compared to rates in the area. Unsafe staffing prior to COVID which worsened once COVID hit. As a charge nurse I many times voiced my concerns in regard to unsafe nurse to patient ratios and/or patient that were higher acuity than where they were placed. The majority of the time I was told that I had “no choice” or that there was “no where else for the patient to go.” I left inpatient when I felt the care I was able to provide my patients was no longer safe. Recent changes were made which took away BSN differential from flex employees.

pros: The interview process is very easy but you’ll see why when you start working here
cons:
DO NOT WASTE YOUR TIME OR ENERGY WORKING HERE !!!!! FULL OF DRAMA AND LIES !!!! Days , evening, night DONT DO IT !!!!
1. The pay SUCKS TMH only gives yu a .$0.30 raise every year 
2. The TMH MAIN LABORATORY IS A REJECT lab everybody who gets kicked out the other labs get placed here so it’s a hostile work environment everyone hates the job and everyone is angry
3. The job is a SCAM it’s advertised as “phlebotomist” but your not doing any phlebotomy really your processing labs the whole entire shift not to mention your running catching tubes every 3 seconds from the tube system. 
4. This job consists of assisting the med lab techs the whole entire shift your delivering the techs specimens and they’re VERY RUDE !!! Not to mention how RUDE MICRO IS!!!! everyone dumps work off on you the whole entire shift no one helps you not even the so called leads !!!! 
5. One lead is super lazy “Day shift lead 4-12 (S)” she SUCKS she will dump work off on yu and your already super busy and she’ll walk off and sit at the computer or in the assistant director office all day doing NOTHING meanwhile your drowning in labs to process she doesn’t care about nothing she is not a team player ! And she definitely doesn’t want to work on call weekends she never signs up on the weekends but wants to force yu to her excuse is her kids ? Why sign up to be a lead if you can’t be one when your team needs you ! 
6. the assistant director (P) doesn’t know nothing about running a lab no lab experience so he doesn’t understand what we’re going threw everyday if he would stop pulling the day shift lead in the office and tell her to help us and stop walking off and taking multiple breaks the work load wouldn’t hurt so bad ! 
7. They lie to you about the on calls ! The on call process is very messy you literally don’t have a life working here ! You can work 5 days be on call your 2 days off and have to work 5 more days so you’d be working 12 days str8t no days off . 
8. The leads are off every weekend. The day shift lead never signs up to work on call on the weekend NEVER but wants to force you to how is that fair ? When she’s off every weekend?! 
9. They hire ANYBODY DRUNKS AND CRACK HEADS LITERALLY!!!!!!
Save yourself the stress and drama and DO NOT WORK HERE !!!!

review_title: The Life of a nurse case manager
job_title: RN Case Manager in Tallahassee, FL
pros:
Excellent support from top level administration
Excellent corporate culture: friendly, reasonable expectations
Great co-workers and team work
Management genuinely listens to staff and strives to make lasting improvements

Supportive of professional development; in house and website educational opportunities
Many fun activities: free barbecue lunches, parties in the cafeteria with nice door prizes, etc.
Case managers are allowed to take time from the work day for MD appointments, etc. without using vacation time (I imagine there would be a limit to this)
cons:
Considering the importance of the job, case managers are underpaid.
Exempt status; no other nurses in the organization are exempt, except management. That means $25/hr can become $15-$20/hr fast on very busy days.
Holidays off require use of paid leave time (vacation)--taking the day off if one has no vacation time is not allowed. The holiday hours will be debited to one's PLT bank.
(Perhaps holidays are factored into the PLT hours credited each pay period.)
Most MDs and other staff have no idea what case managers do; consequently expectations are sometimes unrealistic. (management is working diligently on this problem)

pros: It provide experience in the healthcare field showing the ins and outs of working on the hospital floor at the bottom of the totem pole in regards to status. Being a CNA is the least paid healthcare position who basically does the dirty work when dealing with hospital patients. The cons of this experience is being able to learn about the basics of healthcare and being around valuable information. I can say I've learned a lot from being exposed to different health situation.
cons: The lack of pay is certainly a con. Having to deal with sick and elder patients expose you to things like changing another person diapers or being exposed to bodily fluids which is not a pleasant experience. Also their should be mandatory pay and requirements for advancment. A registered nurse works hand and hand with a CNA and they make at least $20 an hour and I'm that's the under.

review_title: Good morals, poor pay, no place for a nurse that wants to move up in the world
pros: Loved my co-workers, and made some great friends. Better than the alternative in Tallahassee! If you are gonna live in the Panhandle, TMH is where you need to work. Loved my patients
cons: The attitude of management not very affirming of nursing, there was too much blame, not enough encouragement. The CEO  had good intentions. Bad staffing issues, poor nurse:patient ratios. Acuity based staffing model was kind of a joke.

review_title: Comparing Chief Nursing Officer to 2 other hospitals.
pros: Direct management (supervisors) are very friendly and open but limited in power.
cons: Highest level management known to be unfriendly and even insulting to excellent nurses.

pros: I really connected with a small group of coworkers while at TMH. The only reason I lasted as long as I could at TMH was due to the small knit-tight group of coworkers that I had as a support group.
cons: Patient-nurse ratio straddles the line between safe and unsafe quite often. Acuity is not factored as highly as it should be. Often charge nurses simply do not advocate nor support floor staff. The culture at TMH is very divided. Young vs old, doctors vs nurses, this dept vs that dept, management vs staff, dayshift vs night shift. There are many new nurses and not enough experienced nurses to provide quality preceptorship and support after preceptorship. Management is out of touch with the problems of being on the floor. They look at numbers first.

review_title: I thoroughly enjoy working with healthcare in helping patience and being able to meet there needs and make them content.
pros: I enjoyed working with people nurses doctors at a hospital is a way to meet many people many contacts and actually get to care about many different types of problems and illness.
cons: Things are faster technologies gotten better where we have to do more things and we used to do so we all have to work together and sometimes we can be in maybe in a bad mood but we can turn it into a good one.

review_title: Good benefits, only yearly opportunity for raise, which is hospital wide as long as you meet criteria.
pros: Good health, dental, vision benefits. Nice gym membership discount. Generally nice co-workers. Employee events and activities. Good team atmosphere, close knit in individual unit.
cons: The infighting between units is awful, everyone thinks everyone else duties are easy and can be rude and pushy when it comes to coordinating. Raises only occur if you change positions/levels, and annual raise for employees who receive certain scores on evaluations. Last year the hospital built a new ER and my holiday bonus was $59, the year before it was almost $1000.

job_title: Patient Account Specialist in Tallahassee, FL
pros: You learn new challeges every day when patiants come in the ER, with a live or death situation you have to be on your P's 7 Q's to get the job done.
cons: When a child deaths or anyone, It's a said situation and some time yopu would be that one to. That they turn to. So you have to be strong at time when you feel weak.

review_title: Registered Nurse and ND positions being taken over by Philippines
pros:
Training Hospital 
Great cafeteria food
Clean working environment 
Residency programs
cons: If American and Caucasian you're a minority and overlooked and have no voice. The Phillipines are hiring their own and infiltrating management positions. If a RN, they're an ally to their supervisor, and seek to throw you under the bus. You're just a warm body. Stressful environment. Their sick leave policy and procedures are too strict. They don't care you're bleeding to death or a loved one died. Go to work or be disciplined. The nurse residency program is too demanding, and causes further stress on new hires. They just graduated. They don't need homework assignments.

review_title: Not the best...no matter what awards are won
pros:
Autonomy
Salary wasn't bad
Ability to run your department the way that you wish....within limits
cons:
Very poor upper management
No continuity within the organization...you literally felt as though you were working within a different company depending on which unit you were in.
Physicians are treated as gods....never go against one....no matter how wrong they are, you will lose....even if they are breaking the law.

review_title: Eye Opening compared to better organized systems.
pros:
The CHP insurance benefit beats the heck out of the huge deductibles and expense of any other health care insurance I have ever paid out the wazoo for.  CHP covers care very well.
I know I care about others and I know was the lowest salary I have ever earned.
There are good co-workers that really care and feel defeated by those that are not team players.
Patients are great and deserve the very best of compassionate care!
cons:
A experienced, compassionate, intelligent person who has worked at other places and only is taking this position due to relocation to the area arrives to realize that this stand alone hospital is not in certain ways willing to self evaluate its efficiency and general appearance to others.  
TMH should ask others who come from different hospital environments about how they could improve their care to patients and the community.
Those with the power to make change do so as it seems you are not able to see through the eyes of a patient or a stranger.
There are "bitter party of ones" that have been here and no where else for the last 20 and 30 years of their lives eat their new employees especially in certain areas of the hospital.  
I was blown away that this place hires non-experienced nurse for the critical care areas. 
I was blown away that the staff has no consistent formal training program for staff that follows strict preceptor guidelines that enforces the preceptor to treat the trainee with professionalism and up-lifting encouragement.  I recalled being told by one 30 year employee out of her unkind and bitter heart "your not an administrator anymore".  I wonder what unprofessional supervisor who had not right told her I was once a supervisor in the first place. I was a nose to the grind working on the floor nurse with a fancy title that's all!  This is one cruel place when it comes to certain people.  
True to be found that some staff are so unprofessional and know how to be lazy.
You jump to help them with patient care and certain others gladly tell you NO WAY when you ask for fair team help in return.
They need to have nurses who build confidence in procedures.
TMH  needs  look at other systems  or be consulted on how to  organize the flow of access to materials stat needed for the patients. 
I am blown away that the same insulting preceptor didn't review their patients medications and was sending them home with multiple repeated dangerous medications.  I am blown away that a nurse practitioner didn't even catch it and showed attitude at being called to fix the danger the pt. was being placed in by not having the medication addressed and corrected for safe dosage the moment the pt. arrived at the start of there care.
There is hardly a visible spiritual center that is traditional and more visible at other hospitals. Yes, we have ministers that are great.  There needs to be a open and much more visible place for all faiths to come to seek out their higher spiritual needs.  TMH you tuck this away...boast this neutral place for all faiths and non-faiths as a choice for strength reflection needs.   
Promote compassion and professionalism in our care. Demand it of all staff!
The maintenance of electrical lights above beds and in the ceilings are way behind and lacking.  The place may be a  beautiful lady of talented care; however  the problem it that her dress is UGLY. The place needs an internal face lift down to the rooms and the pt. supplies areas are not organized that gives each floor a consistent lay out.  As a new person I was frustrated that it took minutes of staring at the wall of supplies to figure out where an emergent item was at. 
I know the floors have been improved but, there is still too much time/money spent on managing them.  There are far more advanced decor systems that other hospitals are using that could redirect monies to direct care givers allowing TMH to be BSN staffed and attract the best.
The utilizing of buses to transport staff on a ongoing and continuous load of expense.  Stop renting to that slum lord leaking room building next door to the hospital to the sad place to call a  private school.  Build a tower of parking for staff only and charge us a fair fee a month to not have to park our butts on the filthy bus system where we have to sit next to smokers and those coughing all over others.  
Stop getting rid of staff after 6 sick call ins.  I have had to take two off sick because a co-worker was sick and maxed out on sick days...came in coughing and spreading the germs on us in the air. 
I recall how a patient shared with me that she was a former nurse and others fired because became sick from a building of mold at TMH.  Yes, she sued.  Yes, she won...but her illness has taken her to a true low.
Stop your surveys that ask questions about your, age, race, how long you have been an employee and other questions that lead the anonymous survey right to your fingerprints.  If you complain and tell the truth of all the questions you are busted. 
Stop passing staff who are dedicated for training and specialization opportunities because you want to keep them in the hard to fill time slot.  Stop hiring a new person to the area and providing them with the benefit of specialized training.  Practice fair and promotion.
Managers in certain under performing departments. Stop planting snitches among the nursing staff that have all left on you already.  Stop being paranoid and retire so others can get in there treat others as peers and make the patient care the best.

review_title: It has been a fantastic experience!
pros: I love the people here and the environment. It is a great place to work. I love the ICARE values stressed in orientation and adhered to by the colleagues. ICARE: Integrity, Compassion, Accountability, Respect, and Excellence.
cons: A hospital is open 365 days a year so schedules cannot always be very flexible.

pros: Good pay. Good working environment. Great benefits. Paid leave days. No trouble getting requested days off. Paid uniforms. The officers in the department work together well
cons: Having to work holidays. But that's typical in healthcare. Also you are required to obtain a class c CDL at your own expense.

pros: Mark O bryant he is a very good leader and things have changed since he arrived. More investments in making the hospital better.
cons: Low pay for healthcare professionals. Not enough communication between different departments.  Stupid rules and regualtions and not enough respect for the worker.

job_title: Sterile Supply Technician in Tallahassee, FL
pros: The majority of the people that I worked with were very nice, and had a high work ethic. Management was very flexible in regards to taking time off.
cons: The machinery used when I was there was constantly breaking down, which led to some stressful situations involving other medical staff. Occasional breakdowns in communications with management.

job_title: Patient Account Specialist in Tallahassee, FL
pros: Tallahassee Memorial is a great company to work for because this hospital upholds its values and mission statement to the fullest. Patients, families and colleagues are all greeted and treated with the upmost respect. It's a great working environment.
cons: A major component of my job/position requires me to be familiar with the beds/bed assignments for the entire hospital. The only con I have is, not enough rooms to accommodate all patients.

review_title: Best place to work in the panhandle area
pros: Largest facility and the best place to work if you live or want to work in the panhandle area. Most of the staff is friendly and knowledgeable.
cons: Low pay. Minimal opportunities for advancement. Promotions are often based more on who you know that what you know. Some department managers don't promote good employees because they don't want to lose them.

job_title: Technical Support Helpdesk Technician in Tallahassee, FL
pros: Most employees around the organization are friendly. Cafe is good. Clean environment for the most part. Communication is ok as well.
cons: Management and HR not the greatest. Parking is atrocious. Pay and benefits definitely needs some work. Not a family friendly environment of you work there.

pros: Pretty good benefits and stability.  Depending upon the position, accommodating with scheduling.
cons: You are just a number, not a person.  They really don't care about you, as a person or a valued employee.  You are not "a special snowflake"; they can easily replace you.  They apparently don't care about incompetence, especially among the management.

review_title: Start your career here, stay longer than you initially plan.
pros: Community leader in HealthCare, striving to be world class!  Working here has been a great joy for over 10 years.
cons: Very fast paced and at times there just is not enough staff to provide the great care we strive for at TMH.

review_title: Some great people bu disoranized facility
job_title: Patient Care Tech in Tallahassee, FL
pros: Large facility with a lot to offer, some managers are great and will have your back, better teamwork than at other facilities I have worked at, benefits are fairly good
cons: Pay is below average, the will work you overtime and to the point of mental breakdown one day and then de-staff you early the next to avoid paying you overtime.

pros: Progressive hospital with positive mission statement. Pleasant working environment. Work life balance is encouraged. Decent salary and benefits. Yearly bonus which most hospitals no longer offer.
cons: Poor communication between upper management and staff. There are intradisciplinary committees to make the worker bees feel as if they have a say in the decisions about the hospital but ultimately it's still the higher ups making all the decisions.

review_title: TMH is a wonderful place to work.
pros: The benefits program is enticing (i.e.; discounted fitness club membership, in house credit union, retirement employer contributions, and more).
cons: Being a 24/7 work environment, a hospital, holidays time needs to be coordinated. Salary is average when compared to the national average.

pros: working with patients is always very rewarding, fast paced atmosphere, has very good benefits, schedule somewhat flexible, some room for advancement
cons: treated like number that could be easily replaced, too much internal politics and gossip, very anti union, limited time for patient educatuib

pros: Nice workout facility.  Good health Insurance.  Good orientation.  Very good CEO.  Good mission statement.
cons: CEO is great, but the Vice Presidents and product line managers do not follow his lead and undermine his authority.  He needs to clean shop.  TMH tries new and innovative ideas but the sub-management kills all ideas before they can be implemented.  The department heads are very jaded after years of killed initiatives.  They jokei is; TMH where good ideas go to die.

pros: The majority of the employees are very nice
cons: The company is too money hungry. Staff is overworked, underpaid, and under appreciated.

pros: Flexibility with schedule. Depending on what tier you sign up for you ether work a minimum of 4, 6, or 9 shifts in a four week period.
cons: No benefits for PRN employees. Depending on tier even as PRN you are required to work a certain amount of major and minor holidays and weekend hours.

review_title: Typical hospital, thorough orientation, preceptors on the floor, lots of employee activities.
pros: Pays for all CEUs and automatically uploads them to CE Broker, pays for BLS, ACLS, PALS if required for job field. Offers discounted membership to best fitness facility in town opportunities for overtime
cons: Old hospital, not magnet status, difficulty converting from written orders to CPOE, very low hourly pay.

pros: Great coworkers, doctors at the forefront of medicine, everyone loves to teach and learn, fun activities like dessert happy hour and awards for stellar employees
cons: Low pay, though we do make more than the scribes at the other (private) hospital in town

review_title: Excellent company because of the people
pros: Talented management that really cares about the people. Upper management actually understands the entire flow of the physician offices and how everything should work. In my experience, management listened to their employees and got all of the details before making decisions.
cons: Very limited employment opportunities in Tallahassee for the IT sector.

review_title: Be careful who you confide in...
pros: I liked my schedule, the benefits, and the cafeteria (sad I know).
cons: Pay, Management, Unable to use time off without several months of notice, Brown Nosing, Gossip

job_title: Unit Secretary/Monitor Tech in Tallahassee, FL
pros: Fast Paced, Always learning, Flexible schedule, Rarely boring, Caring staff ICU, Valuable experience gained, Opportunity to work with a variety of doctors/specialties.
cons: Sometimes, the work hours aren't very appealing (if you are on call or filing in). Must alternate working holidays/weekends, etc. Pay for unit secretary/monitor tech is very low.

pros:
Friendly staff 
Flexible schedule 
Work/clean at your own pace 
Access to pool, gym, and other amenities for free (sauna, hot tub, nice locker rooms)
cons:
Low salary 
Work by yourself 
Gym members can be very demanding 
More pool maintenance than lifeguarding 
Lifeguard aid room is outside - gets cold during the winter

job_title: Emergency Care Technician in Tallahassee, FL
pros: The nursing staff is great and they are the only thing keeping the ER from crumbling.
cons: Management is lackluster and disconnected. The building is new, but a hodge-podge of half-witted ideas that disrupts flow.

pros: They offer great benefits to employees that are full-time.
cons: The company can show favoritism to some employees and also the staff don't respect each other.

pros: Most staff are awesome. Lots of gatherings
cons: Cant pick shift, Management gives you hard time with using PLT even if requested ahead of time. Lots of favoritism. Lots of gossip, I guess that's expected with work place full of women. Staff speaking native tongues. Staff undermind one another in presence of patients.

pros: Good Christian hard working employees.
cons:
Staffing - one pharmacist to handle main pharmacy orders for a 700+ bed facility. 
Salary - pharmacist salary is in the lowest 15% in the nation. 
Bonus - Christmas bonus 2013 = $87

review_title: Unsafe ratios and management allows bullying
pros:
Pay is decent
Self-scheduling (in most places)
cons:
Management overlooks bullying (3 different departments)
Unsafe ratios
Sick leave policy is unrealistic for working with sick people

job_title: Human Resources Assistant in Tallahassee, FL
pros: I think your experience at TMH is entirely shaped by the people you work with and the people in the HR department are some of the nicest people you'll meet
cons: Pay is not the highest

pros: Great fellow nurses and my floor management couldn't be better.
cons: Lower pay than other local hospitals.  We have too many travelers.  We should get a discount in the caffetiera.

pros: if you are looking for somewhere to volunteer to have some hands on experience this is the perfect place to work.
cons: getting into the swing into things, but once you are able to adapt you will have a great experience

review_title: Wonderful organization leading capital city in health & wellness.
pros: Great collaborative efforts between departments to boost awareness of program, TMH is super open to collaborating with outside facilities and organizations to further expand the breadth of their mission.
cons: Slow to process upward mobility.

pros: Working at one of the most advanced hospitals in the region with rapid growth; Helping improve the lives of Tallahassee and surrounding areas
cons: Parking could be better

pros: There would be an end to the misery..
cons: Horrible staff morale, awful cliques of nurses who treat others outside the "group" like absolute dirt, low pay, unreasonable expectations as to nurse/patient ratio, awful and dishonest management, if you notice how bad it is you better keep it to yourself.

pros: I have been at TMH for 3 and a half years and I love being employed here
cons: Compensation could definitely be a bit more

review_title: It was a good learning experience.
pros: friendly environment, friendly-employees, there is a lot to learn(different areas)
cons: didn't have enough tasks for interns

pros: Working at TMH is definitley a great experience. I recommend it to any FSU,FAMU, TCC, or any other students that want some real world experience.
cons: Not a paid internship which is definitley a negative.

job_title: Social Worker/Case Manager in Tallahassee, FL
pros: Retirement benefits, professional environment, multidisciplinary collaboration
cons: Minimal incentive for advancement, no paid holidays, no clinical supervision provided

pros: Exciting working in the er, patients was often nice and friendly.
cons: Staff was rude, supervisor and manager tried to fire me under unconventional circumstances. They tried to terminate me without proper causes, ignoring the fact I had an on going medical conditions. Went to HR and they did not care

pros: Great co-workers, collaborative environment, diverse clientele and diagnoses
cons: Low pay, no paid holidays, insufficient leave, poor control over dysfunctional management, high stress environment with poor support system

review_title: Best hospital in Tally to work for but crappy pay
pros: teaching environment and constantly growing
cons: pay is horrible for experienced nurses

pros:
Much better than when I started
Nurses and generally the nurse managers are great.
cons:
HR is a filled with Clowns
IT Sucks and they have an autocratic Project Manager

pros: NONE The organization does not care about employees at all.
cons:
Holiday Pay is 10% of your salary---NEVER heard of a facility not paying time and half at least
Do nothing for employees for nurses week, holidays
Full day suspension for a mis labeled lab or lab error---even first time!!
TO MUCH TO LIST

pros: Great people to work with, decent ratios
cons: Not the best pay offered in town

pros: It was a good place to start my first career.
cons: There are not enough nurses to handle all of the patients.

job_title: Patient Care Assistant in Tallahassee, FL
pros: Everyone is fairly nice. Workplace is clean and management is professional enough.
cons: The pay is not good.

pros: Great benefits for the employees once they are full time
cons: Overnight Shift can be a little draining.

review_title: Non profit hospital that serves communities near and far.
pros: the feeling of family . Open door policy
